The specific duties of the Judicial Conférence include surveying ihe conditions of business in the courts of the United States, preparing jans for the assignment of judges to or from courts of appeals or district ourts, promoting uniformity of management procedures and the xpeditious conduct of court business, the reviewing of circuit council’ onduct and disability orders, and carrying on a continuous study of the: jperation and effect of general-rules of practice and procedure in use within the federal courts. In addition, the Judicial Conference supervises. the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts and. perates through a network of committees created to address and advise on ‘yariety of subjects dealing with administration of the courts. The Chief: ystice of the United States is the presiding officer of the conference. émbership is comprised of the chief judges of each judicial circuit, the ef judge of the Court of International Trade, and a-district judge ‘om each regidnal judicial circuit. A circuit chief judge’s term on the onference is concurrent with his or her term as chief judge of the circuit, even years or until seventy yeats of age, whichever comes first. District iidge representatives are elected for terms of not less than three. nor more five successive years, as established.by majority vote of all circuit and district judges of their circuit. A claim must be founded upon the United _ ates Constitution; an act of Congress; the regulation of an executive department; an express or implied-in-fact contract with the United States, ‘ar damages, liquidated or unliquidated, in cases not sounding in tort. ppeals are to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. All judges on the court are appointed by the President, with Senate consent, for 15-year terms.
